name: nitropack
description: Build and deploy universal JavaScript servers

scripts.release: pnpm test && pnpm build && standard-version && pnpm publish && git push --follow-tags

readme:
[![npm version][npm-version-src]][npm-version-href] [![npm downloads][npm-downloads-src]][npm-downloads-href] [![npm-edge version][npm-edge-version-src]][npm-edge-version-href] [![npm-edge downloads][npm-edge-downloads-src]][npm-edge-downloads-href]

‚öóÔ∏è Nitro

Build and deploy universal JavaScript servers!

## Why using Nitro? Nitro provides a powerful toolchain and a runtime framework from the [UnJS](https://github.com/unjs) ecosystem to build and deploy **any JavaScript server, anywhere!** ‚ùØ **Rapid development** experience with hot module replacement
‚ùØ **Multi-provider** deployments with a single codebase and zero-configuration
‚ùØ **Portable and compact** deployments without `node_modules` dependency
‚ùØ **Directory structure** aware to register API routes and more with zero configuration
‚ùØ **Minimal Design** to fit into any solution with minimum overhead
‚ùØ **Code-splitting** and async chunk loading for fast server startup time
‚ùØ **TypeScript** fully supported
‚ùØ **Multi-driver storage** and caching layer
‚ùØ **Route caching** and static **pre-rendering** with built-in crawler
‚ùØ **Hackable** to extend almost any part of nitro using options
‚ùØ **Auto imports** for lazy folks and a tidy minimal codebase
‚ùØ **Best-effort compatibility** for using legacy npm packages and mocking Node.js modules
## Who is using Nitro? [Nuxt 3](https://v3.nuxtjs.org/guide/concepts/server-engine) is using Nitro as its server engine.

üìñ Documentation

‚úçÔ∏è Changelog

üèÄ Online playground


üò∫ Quick Start

0Ô∏è‚É£ Create an empty directory `nitro-app` ```bash mkdir nitro-app cd nitro-app ``` 1Ô∏è‚É£ Create `routes/index.ts`: ```ts [routes/index.ts] export default () => 'nitro is amazing!' ``` 2Ô∏è‚É£ Start development server: ```bash npx nitropack dev ``` ü™Ñ Your API is ready at `http://localhost:3000/` Check `.nitro/dev/index.mjs` if want to know what is happening 3Ô∏è‚É£ You can now build your production-ready server: ```bash npx nitropack build ```` 4Ô∏è‚É£ Output is in the `.output` directory and ready to be deployed on almost any VPS with no dependencies. You can locally try it too: ```bash node .output/server/index.mjs ``` That's it you got it! Read the [documentation](https://nitro.unjs.io) to learn more.

üå± nitro is young and under development

Check [üêõ open issues](https://github.com/unjs/nitro/issues) for the known issues and roadmap and tell us [üí°your ideas](https://github.com/unjs/nitro/discussions/new)!
